prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA pursuing a girl with a boyfriend
This girl and I have been hanging out together since the beginning of the school year. She is so fun and beautiful and vibrant, and has the perfect qualities for a girlfriend. She’s modest and a little shy and totally adorable. I loved hanging out with her and she told me how great I was and how much she loved spending time with me. I was on cloud nine. I really felt like we were moving towards a relationship and developing feelings for each other. Every time she texted me and asked me to hang out, my heart would jump. I was so happy.

Then it all came crashing down when I found out she was dating a guy in our dorm. Not only that, but this guy looks JUST like me. Same race, same build, just very similar, which means I wasn’t wrong in her being attracted to me. I was totally shattered that she pursued this guy instead of me. What did he offer her that I didn’t? Why him? Why was she throwing away the wonderful thing we had brewing between us? I was hurt and stopped talking to her for a few days.

After that, I decided that I wasn’t going to let this bother me. I love her and I love our friendship and the time we spend together. I reached back out and we started hanging out again. I can tell her boyfriend doesn’t like me at all and he’s probably insecure about me, but I don’t care because I love our relationship. However, when I confessed all this to another friend, she called me creepy and threatened to tell the first girl about my feelings if I didn’t come clean or stop pursuing her. Am I the asshole for believing that there’s hope?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out whether the author is in the wrong here. The situation is that he's been hanging out with a girl since the start of the school year, and he feels like they were moving towards a relationship. But then he finds out she's dating someone else who looks a lot like him. He's hurt, stops talking to her for a few days, then tries to reconnect. Now, his friend is calling him creepy because he's still pursuing the girl who's in a relationship.

First, I need to look at the key points. The girl already has a boyfriend, so the author is pursuing her despite that. The fact that she's in a relationship is important because it means the author is trying to get involved with someone who's not available. Even if he thought there was a mutual attraction, once he knows she's dating someone else, continuing to pursue her might be considered inappropriate.

He mentions that she's been texting him and asking to hang out. But if she's in a relationship, maybe she's just maintaining a friendship. The author might be misinterpreting her actions as romantic interest when she's actually just being friendly. Also, the fact that her boyfriend looks like him might mean she's drawn to that type, but that doesn't justify the author's actions. He needs to respect her current relationship.

The friend calls him creepy, which is a strong term. If the author continues to reach out and try to build a relationship with someone who's taken, that could be seen as obsessive or not respecting boundaries. Even if he says he loves their friendship, if she's in a relationship, he should probably step back and not pursue anything romantic, because that's not fair to her or her boyfriend.

So, putting it all together, the author is in the wrong because he's pursuing a girl who is in a relationship. Even though he might have had feelings, once he knew her status, he should have stopped the pursuit. Continuing to do so is inappropriate and could be hurtful.
